name: Ruston and Hornsby 48DS
bio: A “Really Useless Engine” – these small, simple industrial locomotives saw service in many industrial yards but were almost never seen on the boader network.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}A “Really Useless Engine” – these small, simple industrial locomotives saw service in many industrial yards but were almost never seen on the boader network.

name: Ruston and Hornsby 88DS
bio: A mild upgrade in power made the Ruston 88 significantly more effective without vastly increasing cost.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}A mild upgrade in power made the Ruston 88 significantly more effective without vastly increasing cost.

name: Metro-Cammell Class 151
bio: A class of 2 prototype DMUs built to compete for the contract that became the Class 150 fleet purchase. These units suffered with gearbox issues and the BREL type won the contest instead.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}3{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}2.3 tiles{}{SILVER}A class of 2 prototype DMUs built to compete for the contract that became the Class 150 fleet purchase. These units suffered with gearbox issues and the BREL type won the contest instead.

name: BR Class 201 “Thumper” “4S”
bio: Class 201 ‘Hastings’ Units were constructed to a narrow loading gauge to work through a number of limited clearance tunnels in the southern region. Southern DEMUs of the time had their engines mounted above the frames.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}4{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}2.8 tiles{}{SILVER}Class 201 ‘Hastings’ Units were constructed to a narrow loading gauge to work through a number of limited clearance tunnels in the southern region. Southern DEMUs of the time had their engines mounted above the frames.

bio: Class 201 ‘Hastings’ Units were constructed to a narrow loading gauge to work through a number of limited clearance tunnels in the southern region. Southern DEMUs of the time had their engines mounted above the frames.

Southern DEMUs of the time had their engines mounted above the frames.

name: BR Class 205 “Thumper” 3H
bio: Class 205 units were a relatively numerous class of high-density non-corridor multiple units that worked services across Hampshire. In many ways they were the classic ‘Thumper’ unit.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}3{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}2.3 tiles{}{SILVER}Class 205 units were a relatively numerous class of high-density non-corridor multiple units that worked services across Hampshire. In many ways they were the classic ‘Thumper’ unit.

bio: Class 205 units were a relatively numerous class of high-density non-corridor multiple units that worked services across Hampshire. In many ways they were the classic ‘Thumper’ unit.

bio: Class 201 ‘Hastings’ Units were constructed to a narrow loading gauge to work through a number of limited clearance tunnels in the southern region. Southern DEMUs of the time had their engines mounted above the frames.

Southern DEMUs of the time had their engines mounted above the frames.

bio: Class 201 ‘Hastings’ Units were constructed to a narrow loading gauge to work through a number of limited clearance tunnels in the southern region. Southern DEMUs of the time had their engines mounted above the frames.

Southern DEMUs of the time had their engines mounted above the frames.

name: BR Class 302 “AM2”
bio: A suburban Mk1 EMU that mainly operated out of East London on the LT&S line. Here we represent the refurbished condition of these units, which lasted until 1998.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}25kV AC {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}4{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}3.0 tiles{}{SILVER}A suburban Mk1 EMU that mainly operated out of East London on the LT&S line. Here we represent the refurbished condition of these units, which lasted until 1998.

name: BR Class 302/9
bio: A later conversion of the Class 302 to a parcels unit involved the addition of roller doors to the bodyside for faster loading and unloading. The prototypes were also painted in a striking Royal Mail red livery.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}25kV AC {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}3{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}2.3 tiles{}{SILVER}A later conversion of the Class 302 to a parcels unit involved the addition of roller doors to the bodyside for faster loading and unloading. The prototypes were also painted in a striking Royal Mail red livery.

name: BR Class 309/1 “Clacton Express”
bio: The ‘Clacton’ units were iconic express EMUs of the GEML’s early electrification. This subclass represents a 2 car formation, used to boost 2nd class capacity and power on peak time services.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}25kV AC {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}2{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}1.5 tiles{}{SILVER}The ‘Clacton’ units were iconic express EMUs of the GEML’s early electrification. This subclass represents a 2 car formation, used to boost 2nd class capacity and power on peak time services.

name: BR Class 309/2 “Clacton Express”
bio: The ‘Clacton’ units were iconic express EMUs of the GEML’s early electrification. This subclass represents a 4 car formation complete with the famous ‘Griddle Car’ restaurant.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}25kV AC {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}4{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}3.0 tiles{}{YELLOW}25% long distance bonus for consist{}{SILVER}The ‘Clacton’ units were iconic express EMUs of the GEML’s early electrification. This subclass represents a 4 car formation complete with the famous ‘Griddle Car’ restaurant.

name: BR Class 309/3 “Clacton Express”
bio: The ‘Clacton’ units were iconic express EMUs of the GEML’s early electrification. This subclass represents a basic 4 car formation complete.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}25kV AC {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}4{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}3.0 tiles{}{SILVER}The ‘Clacton’ units were iconic express EMUs of the GEML’s early electrification. This subclass represents a basic 4 car formation complete.

name: Alstom Class 458/5 "5JUP"
bio: The suburban conversion of ex-class 460 trains, now through-gangwayed and in 5 car formations. 4 of the former Class 460 baggage vehicles were scrapped as part of the conversion program.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}750V DC {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}5{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}3.8 tiles{}{YELLOW}10% bonus for long distance travel{}{SILVER}The suburban conversion of ex-class 460 trains, now through-gangwayed and in 5 car formations. 4 of the former Class 460 baggage vehicles were scrapped as part of the conversion program.

name: BR Class 411 “4CEP”
bio: The archetypal Mk1 Express EMU – 4CEP units were an evolution of the earlier southern 4COR units. 133 were built and they enjoyed a long career into the early 2000s.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}750V DC {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}4{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}3.0 tiles{}{SILVER}The archetypal Mk1 Express EMU – 4CEP units were an evolution of the earlier southern 4COR units. 133 were built and they enjoyed a long career into the early 2000s.

name: BR Class 419 “MLV”
bio: The Class 419 Motor Luggage Van was used to extend the luggage capacity of express services and was capable of running on it’s own batteries within non-electrified areas.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}750V DC / Battery {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}The Class 419 Motor Luggage Van was used to extend the luggage capacity of express services and was capable of running on it’s own batteries within non-electrified areas.

name: BR Class 489 “GLV”
bio: A late conversion of the 2HAP driving motor to a cab and luggage car for Gatwick Express services
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}750V DC {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}A late conversion of the 2HAP driving motor to a cab and luggage car for Gatwick Express services

name: Leyland/Hunslet Class 153 "Super Sprinter"
bio: The Class 153 was a conversion of earlier Class 155 units, 35 of which were split in two with small cabs added at the inner ends.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}2{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.9 tiles{}{SILVER}The Class 153 was a conversion of earlier Class 155 units, 35 of which were split in two with small cabs added at the inner ends.

name: BREL Class 370 "APT-P" (6 car leading set)
bio: A 6-car half-rake of APT-P vehicles
additional_text: {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}6{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.9 tiles{}{YELLOW}20% bonus for long distance travel{}{SILVER}A 6-car half-rake of APT-P vehicles

bio: A 6-car half-rake of APT-P vehicles
additional_text: {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}6{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.9 tiles{}{YELLOW}20% bonus for long distance travel{}{SILVER}A 6-car half-rake of APT-P vehicles

name: BREL Class 370 "APT-P" (2 car leading set)
bio: A minimal 2-car half-rake of APT-P Vehicles. Lack of dining facilities makes this much less attractive for passengers.
additional_text: {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}2{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}1.5 tiles{}{SILVER}A minimal 2-car half-rake of APT-P Vehicles. Lack of dining facilities makes this much less attractive for passengers.

bio: A minimal 2-car half-rake of APT-P Vehicles. Lack of dining facilities makes this much less attractive for passengers.

name: BREL Class 370 "APT-P" (power car)
bio: An APT-P centre power car
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}25kV AC {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}An APT-P centre power car

name: BREL APT-S Driving Motor
bio: The APT-S was a rework of the APT concept towards more conventional rolling stock, with a driving motor car, articulated trailers and a DVT.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}25kV AC {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.9 tiles{}{SILVER}The APT-S was a rework of the APT concept towards more conventional rolling stock, with a driving motor car, articulated trailers and a DVT.

name: BREL APT-S/Q Driving Van Trailer
bio: The APT-Q was proposed to rationalise existing APT-P stock into usable 6-car tains, with a single non-driving power car and a new-build DVT.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.9 tiles{}{SILVER}The APT-Q was proposed to rationalise existing APT-P stock into usable 6-car tains, with a single non-driving power car and a new-build DVT.

name: BREL "APT-S" Trailer Rake (10 cars)
bio: An articulated trailer rake of APT-S Vehicles, intended to run with a Driving Motor and a DVT
additional_text: {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}10{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}7.5 tiles{}{YELLOW}20% bonus for long distance travel{}{SILVER}An articulated trailer rake of APT-S Vehicles, intended to run with a Driving Motor and a DVT

name: BREL "APT-S" Trailer Rake (6 cars)
bio: An articulated trailer rake of APT-S Vehicles, intended to run with a Driving Motor and a DVT
additional_text: {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}6{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}4.5 tiles{}{YELLOW}20% bonus for long distance travel{}{SILVER}An articulated trailer rake of APT-S Vehicles, intended to run with a Driving Motor and a DVT

name: BR Class 73/9 “Ultra73”
bio: These re-engined and modernized Class 73s retained their ability to run from the third rail but received diesel engines capable of operating at an equivalent power level.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.7 tiles{}{SILVER}These re-engined and modernized Class 73s retained their ability to run from the third rail but received diesel engines capable of operating at an equivalent power level.

name: RCH Salt Wagon
bio: The standard RCH Salt Wagon design of 1907 was long-lived in private ownership and saw some use beyond sodium chloride, which was largely used as part of the chemical industry.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}The standard RCH Salt Wagon design of 1907 was long-lived in private ownership and saw some use beyond sodium chloride, which was largely used as part of the chemical industry.

name: “Presflo” Powder Hopper
bio: The Presflo covered hopper was designed specifically to carry cement powder, being unloaded via a pressurized air connection and liquefaction of the cargo.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}The Presflo covered hopper was designed specifically to carry cement powder, being unloaded via a pressurized air connection and liquefaction of the cargo.

name: PCA Powder Tanker
bio: The PCA tanker, with it’s notable depressed-center ‘vee’ appearance, could carry large amounts of cement and was a common sight in mixed freight trains.
additional_text: #N/A

name: JPA Powder Tanker
bio: By the 2000s the BR-era 2-axle cement tankers then in use were beginning to show their age. They were replaced by these large bogie tank wagons built in Germany, with a distinctive fish-belly shape.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.7 tiles{}{SILVER}By the 2000s the BR-era 2-axle cement tankers then in use were beginning to show their age. They were replaced by these large bogie tank wagons built in Germany, with a distinctive fish-belly shape.

name: BR Grain Hopper
bio: The LMS Grain Hooper was later standardised into the BR COVGRAIN standard design, built in significant numbers to standardise the carriage of this important traffic.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}The LMS Grain Hooper was later standardised into the BR COVGRAIN standard design, built in significant numbers to standardise the carriage of this important traffic.

name: “Grainflow” Covered Hopper
bio: The BR ‘Whiskey Covhops’ were a common sight on long-distance freight trains from southern England, headed for the distilleries of Scotland.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.7 tiles{}{SILVER}The BR ‘Whiskey Covhops’ were a common sight on long-distance freight trains from southern England, headed for the distilleries of Scotland.

name: “Polybulk” Covered Hopper
bio: Large bogie covered hoppers first appeared in Britain in the mid 1970s. These were frequently privately owned and registered as international vehicles. This slab-sided ‘Polybulk’ example was built in France.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.7 tiles{}{SILVER}Large bogie covered hoppers first appeared in Britain in the mid 1970s. These were frequently privately owned and registered as international vehicles. This slab-sided ‘Polybulk’ example was built in France.

name: LNWR Sleeping Car
bio: Early 20th century sleeping cars were often heavier and larger than their daytime counterparts. This represents a wooden-bodied, 6-axle sleeping coach of the golden era of train travel, in reality there were many variants built in many batches.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{YELLOW}50% bonus for long distance travel{}{SILVER}Early 20th century sleeping cars were often heavier and larger than their daytime counterparts. This represents a wooden-bodied, 6-axle sleeping coach of the golden era of train travel, in reality there were many variants built in many batches.

name: BR Mk1 Sleeper
bio: The Mk1 Sleeper was built in relatively large numbers. The type was not especially popular with passengers, but the service was still an improvement on sleeping in ordinary compartment stock of the time.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{YELLOW}50% bonus for long distance travel{}{SILVER}The Mk1 Sleeper was built in relatively large numbers. The type was not especially popular with passengers, but the service was still an improvement on sleeping in ordinary compartment stock of the time.

name: BR Mk3 Sleeper
bio: The Mk3 Sleeper was a significant upgrade over the previous stock – being air conditioned and air sprung. Two berths per cabin unfortunately give these vehicles a low capacity. This represents a typical Sleeper, Either Class, Pantry (SLEP) vehicle.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.9 tiles{}{YELLOW}50% bonus for long distance travel{}{SILVER}The Mk3 Sleeper was a significant upgrade over the previous stock – being air conditioned and air sprung. Two berths per cabin unfortunately give these vehicles a low capacity. This represents a typical Sleeper, Either Class, Pantry (SLEP) vehicle.
